title: One Savings and Charter Savings merge but keep double FSCS protection
text:
Savers who have money deposited with Kent Reliance, part of One Savings Bank, and Charter Savings Bank have been told their compensation scheme coverage limits are to be protected following a merger between the pair.

The deal to combine the two challenger banks completed today and means both One Savings Bank and Charter Savings Bank are now technically one company.

Under the terms of most mergers like this, savers would typically see their Financial Services Compensation Scheme coverage reduce as a direct result of the merger - those with money in both banks would need to shift some elsewhere.

But This is Money has been told that savers who hold money with both Charter Savings and One Savings, under the Kent Reliance brand, will retain the cash protection limits for both - which at double £85,000 comes to a total of £170,000.

Under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme, savers are guaranteed to get the first £85,000 of their savings in a bank or building society back in the unlikely event it collapses

Under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme, savers are guaranteed to get the first £85,000 of their savings in a bank or building society back in the unlikely event it collapses.

The limit covers all the money you have with that institution in easy-access accounts, fixed-rate bonds, cash Isas, notice accounts and current accounts.

However, your money is only covered up to £85,000 per banking institution, od double that for joint accounts.

Earlier this year Virgin Money was bought by Clydesdale and Yorkshire Bank Group, resulting in savers losing some of their FSCS protection if they held more than £85,000 across the three brands.

This was because under the terms of that deal, Virgin Money and CYBG moved to share a single banking licence.

Customers saving with One Savings and Charter Savings will benefit from the higher FSCS limit because they plan to retain two separate banking licences for the foreseeable future.

A statement from One Savings Bank said: 'Nothing has changed for customers, and all deposits up to £85,000 in both Kent Reliance and Charter Savings Bank are still covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme deposit guarantee scheme and backed by the combined company’s strong capital position.

'Both OneSavings Bank and Charter Court Financial Services banking licences have been retained, meaning there is no dilution of FSCS eligible deposits for customers of both brands. There are no plans at present to change this.'
